metadata.titel_preek: Ash Wednesday & First Sunday in Lent

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in the human condition of universal sin and self-deception to justify the ungodly through the substitutionary death of Christ.

tekstueel_bewijs: God has shown us a great thing
Jesus... has voluntarily taken our place
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies

object.identificatie: Salvation / Mercy / Justification of the ungodly
tekstueel_bewijs: salvation of each and every one of us

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Holiness of God
tekstueel_bewijs: the reality of God... who has the absolute right to make demands
show mercy to us all, especially to the perpetrators
the salvation of each and every one of us

helper.identificatie: Jesus Christ / The Holy Spirit (implied in prayer)
tekstueel_bewijs: There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin / Self-deception / The Wrath of God / Death
tekstueel_bewijs: the storm of the wrath of God against sin
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is treated as a theological reality and a cosmic power that requires a divine death to nullify, not just a moral mistake.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of repentance and honest self-inventory (Lent).
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer / The Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The preacher explicitly states that the knowledge of grace precedes the confession of sin.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has shown us a great thing.
Jesus... has voluntarily taken our place.
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We throw ourselves on his mercy.
We can let ourselves be seen as the sinners we really are.

voorbeelden: Our temptation will be... to try to squirm off the hook.
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession.
God is truly able to do away with sin.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on God's 'ability' (Pouvoir) to save, which creates the 'knowledge' (Savoir) in the hearer that makes confession possible.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From ~S1 (Pretense) to S2 (Judgment acknowledged) to S1 (Grace received) which enables ~S2 (Repentance).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ takes S2 (Judgment) to open S1 (Grace) for those in ~S1 (Pretense).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; the 'storm of the wrath of God' is explicitly mentioned.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It identifies God as the primary actor in salvation and treats human repentance as a response to, rather than a condition for, divine mercy.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Repentance is necessary for human well-being.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself.
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures (David) and historical figures (Tolkien, Lincoln) are used to illustrate the human condition or the logic of insight, not as moral templates for earning favor.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: The Psalmist (as one who sees reality)
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: God is the one who creates the clean heart.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'exhausting charade' of self-justification.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic undertones; salvation is entirely God's work.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'searching self-inventory' to the 'substitutionary work of Christ' is seamless and logically grounded in the priority of grace.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'sinning against God only' and the horizontal harm of sin is resolved through the definition of sin as a theological concept.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is mentioned in the Trinitarian formula but the 'Pouvoir' is attributed directly to Christ's work.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is an offense against the 'author of all goodness' requiring divine death.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject of the primary narrative program. The hearer is positioned as the Receiver of an objective work (Christ's death).

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain current balance; it serves the Ash Wednesday context well.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Perhaps link the 'Savoir' (Insight) more explicitly to the 'Pouvoir' of the Holy Spirit.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a textbook example of grace-oriented homiletics. It avoids the trap of making repentance a 'work' by grounding the ability to confess in the prior reality of God's mercy.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the use of Tolkien or Solzhenitsyn as 'hooks', Greimasian analysis reveals these are actantial 'Opponents' to the Subject's self-deception.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis might focus on the Hebrew of Psalm 51; this analysis focuses on how the preacher re-assigns the 'Subject' role from the Psalmist to Christ.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the 'genius' of the sermon lies in the Subject-switch: the hearer starts as the Subject of 'self-inventory' but is quickly moved to the Receiver of Christ's 'Performance'.

appendices.notities: The sermon adheres strictly to Fleming Rutledge's 'Grammar of Grace'.
